title: Question 62

children: A 66-year-old woman is seen for a preoperative medical evaluation before total right knee arthroplasty. Medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and peripheral vascular disease. Medications are rivaroxaban, metoprolol, losartan, and atorvastatin.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The physical examination documents osteoarthritis of the knee and an irregular heart rhythm.
Laboratory studies show a
serum creatinine
level of 1.0 mg/dL (88.4 Âµmol/L) and an
estimated glomerular filtration rate
greater than 60 mL/min/1.73 m
Which of the following is the most appropriate perioperative management of the patient's rivaroxaban?

text.__html: Continue rivaroxaban until day of surgery
Withhold rivaroxaban 3 days before surgery; bridge with low-molecular-weight heparin
Withhold rivaroxaban 7 days before surgery; bridge with low-molecular-weight heparin

children: In patients with normal kidney function, withholding a direct oral anticoagulant for four half-lives (2-3 days) reduces anticoagulant levels to approximately 6.25%, resulting in near-normal bleeding risk.
Direct oral anticoagulants have a rapid onset and short half-life; thus, bridging anticoagulation is not needed.
The most appropriate perioperative management of the patient's rivaroxaban is to withhold for 3 days before surgery (
Option B

). Before elective surgery, management decisions about anticoagulant therapy are made on the basis of surgical bleeding risk, thrombotic risk off anticoagulants, kidney function, and type of drug. In this case, the patient is taking rivaroxaban, a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC), for atrial fibrillation. She has a moderate-high CHA
DS

-VASc score of 4 (hypertension, age, vascular disease, female) and normal kidney function and is undergoing a surgery with moderate bleeding risk. Because of the bleeding risk, she should not be anticoagulated at the time of surgery. In patients with normal kidney function, withholding a DOAC for four half-lives (2-3 days) reduces anticoagulant levels to approximately 6.25%, resulting in near-normal bleeding risk. Thus, withholding rivaroxaban 3 days before surgery in this patient is recommended.

Although anticoagulation can be continued until the day of surgery for select minor procedures (e.g., cataract or dental surgery), patients undergoing surgery with significant bleeding risk must have anticoagulation withheld long enough to ensure adequate drug clearance and normalization of coagulation. Continuing rivaroxaban until the day of surgery (
Option A
) places this patient at an unacceptable bleeding risk perioperatively.

Patients who are at especially high risk for thrombosis while off anticoagulants may need a pre- or postoperative anticoagulant bridge with low-molecular-weight heparin to limit time off anticoagulation. This is most relevant for drugs with a delayed onset of action and longer half-life, such as warfarin. DOACs, however, have a rapid onset and short half-life; thus, bridging anticoagulation is not needed. The BRIDGE trial demonstrated no difference in thrombotic events in patients on warfarin with atrial fibrillation who were bridged perioperatively but did observe a higher rate of bleeding in this group. Therefore, bridging anticoagulation is rarely recommended, except in the setting of very high thrombosis risk off warfarin therapy, such as atrial fibrillation with a mechanical heart valve. This patient is not at very high risk for thrombosis and is not on warfarin; therefore, bridging is not warranted (
Options C, E
Withholding rivaroxaban for 7 days before surgery (
Option D
) is unlikely to provide additional benefit from a bleeding standpoint and may increase the risk for thrombosis by lengthening the time the patient is off anticoagulation.

objective.__html: Manage direct oral anticoagulant therapy for an elective surgical procedure.

references: Lip GY, Banerjee A, Boriani G, et al. Antithrombotic therapy for atrial fibrillation: CHEST guideline and expert panel report. Chest. 2018;154:1121-201.
